lead_paragraph: A police raid in Bulgaria was heralded as a rare success against the trafficking of antiquities, but it also highlighted the barriers officials face.

byline.contributor: Milen Enchev contributed reporting from Sofia, Bulgaria, and Ceylan Yeginsu from Istanbul.
byline.original: By STEVEN LEE MYERS and NICHOLAS KULISH

headline.print_headline: Militants Profit From Looting of Antiquities
headline.main: ‘Broken System’ Allows ISIS to Profit From Looted Antiquities

snippet: A police raid in Bulgaria was heralded as a rare success against the trafficking of antiquities, but it also highlighted the barriers officials face.
abstract: Islamic State is taking advantage of weak and inconsistent international system of laws and customs enforcement in order to profit from antiquities looting; experience and patience of smugglers and value of looted objects to art dealers has made enforcement of anti-smuggling laws difficult; flood of objects looted from sites in Syria and Iraq is expected to reach hungry markets in Western Europe and America over several years.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
